forum.intro:
Introduction

In this activity, you will watch a 20-minute video of a lesson using a rich task that promotes mathematical discourse and conceptual learning. After watching the lesson, you will participate in a discussion forum. Before you begin, let’s review the norms for watching classroom videos.

  • Video clips are examples, not exemplars.
  • Video clips are for investigation of teaching and learning, not evaluation of the teacher.
  • Video clips are snapshots of teaching, not the entire lesson.
  • Video clips are for examination of a particular interaction.

Observation Preparation

In Session 2.1, we discussed the importance of rich math tasks that foster conceptual understanding of mathematics concepts. In this activity, you will observe a lesson that uses a rich math task to engage students in mathematical discourse. In the lesson, learners are asked to analyze a set of salary raises for three employees.

Before watching the video:

  1. Review the handout Comparing Salary Increases, which shows the problem students are working on in the video.
  2. Think about how you would prepare to implement this task with your learners. What methods might they use to solve the problem? What questions might they have? Where are the places that you think they may struggle?

Comparing Salary Increases Lesson Observation

Now you will observe the lesson. As you watch, jot down notes about what you observe. You will use these notes to craft your thoughts in the discussion forum below.

Discussion

Share your reflections on the video in the discussion forum below. Click ADD DISCUSSION TOPIC to add a post to the forum. You may consider responding to the following questions:

  • What teaching strategies did you observe in the lesson that you would like to implement in your classroom to support students making their thinking visible?
  • How might you modify this lesson to meet the needs of your own learners?

You may also share any additional thoughts about the lesson that you would like to discuss.

Read and respond to others’ postings so that this board acts as a collaborative virtual discussion about the lesson. (Click “Discuss this topic” on an individual post, then click “Reply” to respond to that post.)
